key_points: Exascale systems require both high resource efficiency (lightweight OSes) and support for heterogeneous hardware.
Argo Exascale node OS aims to provide both lightweight environments and full OS functionality in a single kernel.
The approach uses OS specialization with multiple containers on top of a Linux kernel.

section: 2015 IEEE International Conference on Cloud Engineering
key_points: Traditional HPC OSes have limited OS-bypass, while lean OSes expose more resources to the HPC runtime.
Figure 1 illustrates the difference between traditional and lean HPC OS architectures.
The Argo project aims to expose most hardware resources to the HPC runtime.

section: II. ESTABLISHING THE NEED FOR OS SPECIALIZATION
key_points: Modern Linux kernels are large and complex, while lightweight kernels like CNK offer better performance.
The Argo project aims for a lean OS while still supporting legacy applications that require a full Linux environment.
Exascale systems will have heterogeneous resources (CPUs, accelerators, memory) requiring complex hardware management.
OS specialization allows for different OS environments tailored to specific workloads and resources.
Existing container technologies (Docker, LXC) focus on isolation and resource sharing, while Argo focuses on exclusive resource partitioning and OS specialization.
Other research projects have explored radical OS changes for heterogeneous systems (Corey, Barrelfish, Multikernel).
The Argo NodeOS aims for a middle ground: OS specialization via containers on top of a single Linux kernel, balancing leanness with compatibility and legacy support.
Exascale systems benefit from reduced OS interference and offloading hardware management to the runtime.
The Argo NodeOS uses OS specialization via containers on a single Linux kernel to achieve both leanness and compatibility.
New resource controllers are being developed to enhance OS specialization capabilities.
